description: From Middle English couren, cowre, from Middle Low German kûren (“to lie in wait; linger”) or from North Germanic (Icelandic kúra (“to doze”)). Cognate with German kauern (“to squat”), Dutch koeren (“to keep watch (in a cowered position)”), Serbo-Croatian kutriti (“to lie in a bent position”), Swedish kura (“huddle, cower”). Unrelated to coward, which is of Latin origin.

verbs.description: cower (third-person singular simple present cowers, present participle cowering, simple past and past participle cowered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To crouch or cringe, or to avoid or shy away from something, in fear.
examples: He'd be useless in war. He'd just cower in his bunker until the enemy came in and shot him, or until the war was over.
Some sterner virtues o’er the mountain’s breastMay sit, like falcons, cowering on the nest

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to cower; to frighten into submission.
